org.jetel.component

Class CustomizedRecordTransform

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jetel.component.CustomizedRecordTransform
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RecordTransform, Transform

    public class CustomizedRecordTransform
extends java.lang.Object
implements RecordTransform
    Class used for generating data transformation. It has methods for mapping input fields on output fields, assigning constants, sequence methods and parameter's values to output fields.

    Patterns for data fields can be given in three ways:

    1. record.field where record is number, name or wild card of input or output record and field is name, number or wild card of record's data field
    2. ${record.field} where record and field have to be as described above
    3. ${in/out.record.field} where record and field have to be as described above

    Order of execution/methods call

    1. setGraph()
    2. setFieldPolicy(PolicyType) - default value is STRICT
    3. setUseAlternativeRules(boolean) - default is false
    4. add...Rule(...)
      .
    5. deleteRule(...)
      .
    6. init()
    7. transform() for each input&output records pair
    8. optionally getMessage() or signal() or getSemiResult()
    9. finished()

    Example:

    Records: 
     in:
 #0|Name|S->  HELLO 
 #1|Age|N->135.0
 #2|City|S->Some silly longer string.
 #3|Born|D->
 #4|Value|d->-999.0000000000
 
 in1:
 #0|Name|S->  My name 
 #1|Age|N->13.25
 #2|City|S->Prague
 #3|Born|D->Thu Nov 30 09:54:07 CET 2006
 #4|Value|i->
 out:
 #0|Name|B->
 #1|Age|N->
 #2|City|S->
 #3|Born|D->
 #4|Value|d->
 out1:
 #0|Name|S->  
 #1|Age|d->
 #2|City|S->
 #3|Born|D->
 #4|Value|i->
    Java code: 
     CustomizedRecordTransform transform = new CustomizedRecordTransform(LogFactory.getLog(this.getClass()));
 transform.setGraph(graph);
 transform.addFieldToFieldRule("${1.?a*}", "${1.*e}");
 transform.addFieldToFieldRule("*.City", 0, 2);
 transform.addConstantToFieldRule(1, 3, new GregorianCalendar(1973, 3, 23).getTime());
 transform.addConstantToFieldRule(4, "1.111111111");
 transform.addSequenceToFieldRule("*.Age", graph.getSequence("ID"));
 transform.addRule("out.City", "${seq.ID.nextString}");
 transform.addParameterToFieldRule(1, 0, "${WORKSPACE}");
 transform.addParameterToFieldRule(1, "City", "YourCity");
 transform.deleteRule(1, "Age");
 transform.init(properties, new DataRecordMetadata[] { metadata, metadata1 }, new DataRecordMetadata[] { metaOut,
                metaOut1 });
 List<String> rules = transform.getRules();
 System.out.println("Rules:");
 for (Iterator<String> i = rules.iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
        System.out.println(i.next());
 }
 rules = transform.getResolvedRules();
 System.out.println("Resolved rules:");
 for (Iterator<String> i = rules.iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
        System.out.println(i.next());
 }
 List<Integer[]> fields = transform.getFieldsWithoutRules();
 System.out.println("Fields without rules:");
 Integer[] index;
 for (Iterator<Integer[]> i = fields.iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
        index = i.next();
        System.out.println(outMatedata[index[0]].getName() + CustomizedRecordTransform.DOT
                        + outMatedata[index[0]].getField(index[1]).getName());
 }
 fields = transform.getNotUsedFields();
 System.out.println("Not used input fields:");
 for (Iterator<Integer[]> i = fields.iterator(); i.hasNext();) {
        index = i.next();
        System.out.println(inMetadata[index[0]].getName() + CustomizedRecordTransform.DOT
                        + inMetadata[index[0]].getField(index[1]).getName());
 }
 transform.transform(new DataRecord[] { record, record1 }, new DataRecord[] { out, out1 });
 System.out.println(record.getMetadata().getName() + ":\n" + record.toString());
 System.out.println(record1.getMetadata().getName() + ":\n" + record1.toString());
 System.out.println(out.getMetadata().getName() + ":\n" + out.toString());
 System.out.println(out1.getMetadata().getName() + ":\n" + out1.toString());
    Output: 
      Rules:
  FIELD_RULE:${1.?a*}=${1.*e}
  FIELD_RULE:*.City=0.2
  CONSTANT_RULE:1.3=Apr 23, 1973
  CONSTANT_RULE:0.4=1.111111111
  SEQUENCE_RULE:*.Age=ID
  SEQUENCE_RULE:out.City=ID.nextString
  PARAMETER_RULE:1.0=${WORKSPACE}
  PARAMETER_RULE:1.City=YourCity
  DELETE_RULE:1.Age=1.Age
  Resolved rules:
  out.Age=${seq.ID}
  out.City=${seq.ID.nextString}
  out.Value=1.111111111
  out1.Name=/home/avackova/workspace
  out1.City=London
  out1.Born=23-04-1973
  out1.Value=in1.Value
  Fields without rules:
  out.Name
  out.Born
  out1.Age
  Not used input fields:
  in.Name
  in.Age
  in.City
  in.Born
  in.Value
  in1.Name
  in1.Age
  in1.City
  in1.Born
  in:
  #0|Name|S->  HELLO 
  #1|Age|N->135.0
  #2|City|S->Some silly longer string.
  #3|Born|D->
  #4|Value|d->-999.0000000000
  
  in1:
  #0|Name|S->  My name 
  #1|Age|N->13.25
  #2|City|S->Prague
  #3|Born|D->Thu Nov 30 10:40:15 CET 2006
  #4|Value|i->
  
  out:
  #0|Name|B-> 
  #1|Age|N->2.0
  #2|City|S->1
  #3|Born|D->
  #4|Value|d->1.1
  
  out1:
  #0|Name|S->/home/user/workspace
  #1|Age|d->
  #2|City|S->London
  #3|Born|D->23-04-1973
  #4|Value|i->
    Since:
    Nov 16, 2006

      This method puts mapping into given output and input field to transform map if theese fields have correct types due to policy type

      void reset()
      Deprecated. 
      static java.lang.String resolveField(java.lang.String pattern)
      Changes pattern given in one of possible format to record.field
      void setFieldPolicy(PolicyType fieldPolicy)
      Sets the field policy: PolicyType.STRICT - mapped output and input fields have to be of the same types PolicyType.CONTROLLED - mapped input fields have to be subtypes of output fields
      PolicyType.LENIENT - field's types are not checked during initialization For PolicyType CONTROLLED and LENIENT method transform can work slower as for not identical types for is called method fromString, when method setValue has failed.
      void setGraph(TransformationGraph graph) 
      void setLogger(org.apache.commons.logging.Log logger)

      Switchs on/off alternative rules.

      • addRule

        public void addRule(java.lang.String patternOut,
           java.lang.String pattern)
        Method for adding rule in CloverETL syntax This method calls proper add....Rule depending on syntax of pattern
        Parameters:
        patternOut - output field's pattern
        pattern - rule for output field as: ${par.parameterName}, ${seq.sequenceID}, ${in.inRecordPattern.inFieldPattern}. If "pattern" doesn't much to any above, it is regarded as constant.
        See Also:
        CodeParser

      • preExecute

        public void preExecute()
                throws ComponentNotReadyException
        Description copied from interface: Transform
        Called during each graph run before the transform is executed. May be used to allocate and initialize resources required by the transform. All resources allocated within this method should be released by the Transform.postExecute() method.
        Specified by:

        Throws:

                 throws ComponentNotReadyException

      • putMappingByNames

        protected int putMappingByNames(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,org.jetel.component.Rule> transformMap,
                    java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,org.jetel.component.Rule>> alternativeMaps,
                    java.lang.String[] outFields,
                    java.lang.String[] inFields,
                    java.lang.String rule)
                         throws ComponentNotReadyException
        Method, which puts mapping rules to map. First it tries to find fields with identical names in corresponding input and output metadata. If not all output fields were found it tries to find them in other input records. If not all output fields were found it tries to find fields with the same names ignoring case in corresponding record. If still there are some output fields without paire it tries to find fields with the same name ignoring case in other records, eg.
        outFieldsNames:
        • lname, fname, address, phone
        • Lname, fname, id
        inFieldsNames:
        • Lname, fname, id, address
        • lname, fname, phone
        Mapping:
        • 0.0 <-- 1.0
        • 0.1 <-- 0.1
        • 0.2 <-- 0.3
        • 0.3 <-- 1.2
        • 1.0 <-- 0.0
        • 1.1 <-- 1.1
        • 1.2 <-- 0.2
        Parameters:
        transformMap - map to put rules
        alternativeMaps - list of alternative maps, used if useAlternativeRules=true and primery map contains output field
        outFields - output fields to mapping
        inFields - input fields for mapping
        Returns:
        number of mappings put to transform map
        Throws:
        ComponentNotReadyException

      • putMapping

        protected boolean putMapping(int outRecNo,
                 int outFieldNo,
                 int inRecNo,
                 int inFieldNo,
                 java.lang.String ruleString,
                 java.util.Map<java.lang.String,org.jetel.component.Rule> transformMap,
                 java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,org.jetel.component.Rule>> alternativeMaps)
                      throws ComponentNotReadyException
        This method puts mapping into given output and input field to transform map if theese fields have correct types due to policy type
        Parameters:
        outRecNo - number of record from output metadata
        outFieldNo - number of field from output metadata
        inRecNo - number of record from input metadata
        inFieldNo - number of field from input metadata
        transformMap -
        alternativeMaps - list of alternative maps, used if useAlternativeRules=true and primery map contains output field
        Returns:
        true if mapping was put into map, false in other case
        Throws:
        ComponentNotReadyException

      • transform

        public int transform(DataRecord[] sources,
            DataRecord[] target)
              throws TransformException
        Description copied from interface: RecordTransform
        Performs reformat of source records to target records. This method is called as one step in transforming flow of records.
        For example in simple reformat situation, for one input record, one output record has to be generated. Thus for each incoming record, this method is called by Reformat component.
        The number of source records (sources[]) and target records (target[]) depends on particular component configuration. Can be 1:1 , N:1 or N:M.
        Specified by:
        transform in interface RecordTransform
        Parameters:
        sources - Source DataRecords
        target - Target DataRecord
        Returns:
        RecordTransform.ALL -- send the data record(s) to all the output ports
        RecordTransform.SKIP -- skip the data record(s)
        >= 0 -- send the data record(s) to a specified output port
        < -1 -- fatal error / user defined
        Throws:
        TransformException

      • transformOnError

        public int transformOnError(java.lang.Exception exception,
                   DataRecord[] sources,
                   DataRecord[] target)
                     throws TransformException
        Description copied from interface: RecordTransform
        Performs reformat of source records to target records. This method is called as one step in transforming flow of records.
        For example in simple reformat situation, for one input record, one output record has to be generated. Thus for each incoming record, this method is called by Reformat component.
        The number of source records (sources[]) and target records (target[]) depends on particular component configuration. Can be 1:1 , N:1 or N:M.
        Called only if RecordTransform.transform(DataRecord[], DataRecord[]) throws an exception.
        Specified by:
        transformOnError in interface RecordTransform
        Parameters:
        exception - an exception that caused RecordTransform.transform(DataRecord[], DataRecord[]) to fail
        sources - Source DataRecords
        target - Target DataRecord
        Returns:
        RecordTransform.ALL -- send the data record(s) to all the output ports
        RecordTransform.SKIP -- skip the data record(s)
        >= 0 -- send the data record(s) to a specified output port
        < -1 -- fatal error / user defined
        Throws:
        TransformException

      • getFieldPolicy

        public PolicyType getFieldPolicy()

      • setFieldPolicy

        public void setFieldPolicy(PolicyType fieldPolicy)
        Sets the field policy:
        • PolicyType.STRICT - mapped output and input fields have to be of the same types
        • PolicyType.CONTROLLED - mapped input fields have to be subtypes of output fields
        • PolicyType.LENIENT - field's types are not checked during initialization
        For PolicyType CONTROLLED and LENIENT method transform can work slower as for not identical types for is called method fromString, when method setValue has failed.
        Parameters:
        fieldPolicy -

        public boolean isUseAlternativeRules()

        if transformation uses alternative rules
        See Also:
        setUseAlternativeRules

      • setUseAlternativeRules

        public void setUseAlternativeRules(boolean useAlternativeRules)
        Switchs on/off alternative rules. When alternative rules are switched on, more rules can be used for one field: if value from primery rule is null or transformations failed trying to set it, there are used lternative rules. Tranasformation fails if value of noone rule can be set to requested field.
        Parameters:
        useAlternativeRules -
